page.title: 03Plym valley ecology
page.content: The steep_sided vally of the Plym runs north to south. The weather is variable with similar rainfall pattern to Plymouth. In the sheltered vally bottom the climate is much warmer and the air humid. Over night and early morning mists are common and billow up to the level of the army camp. These conditions promote growth of lichens ,mosses and ferns. Some flat alluvial stretches near the river have rank grass and rushes alternating with patches ofscrub-mainly willow,alder and blackthorn.The primary climax vegetation of the slopes is deciduous woodland,mostly oak,with a carpet of woodrush and bluebells.Much of this timber has been felled and replaced by mixed conifers planted about 35 years ago.These trees now form dense forest with undergrowth only in the rides where brack and bramble edge the grass
